text: Take advantage of the opportunities in downtown Atlanta and choose from the largest selection of bachelor’s degree programs in the state at a university known as a national leader for its commitment to student success.

At Perimeter College, choose from more than 30 associate degree fields of study available at five metro Atlanta campuses. Complete your two-year degree or transition to the Atlanta Campus to pursue a bachelor’s degree.

At one of the fastest growing research universities in the nation, our faculty and scholars are changing the ways people see the world. Choose from top-ranked professional and graduate programs to take the next step.

At Perimeter College, choose from more than 30 associate degree fields of study available at five metro Atlanta campuses. Complete your two-year degree or transition to the Atlanta Campus to pursue a bachelor’s degree.

Take advantage of the opportunities in downtown Atlanta and choose from the largest selection of bachelor’s degree programs in the state at a university known as a national leader for its commitment to student success.

At one of the fastest growing research universities in the nation, our faculty and scholars are changing the ways people see the world. Choose from top-ranked professional and graduate programs to take the next step.

Ranked as the number two most innovative institution in the country, Georgia State is on the move and on the rise. Few institutions have come so far, so fast. We’re recognized as a national leader in student success. We have one of the fastest growing research profiles in the country. We are changing the way our students are learning, helping them graduate faster, be more productive and save millions on the pathway to their degrees. It’s no wonder The Washington Post called us a “hotbed of growth and innovation.”
with us? Our students come from every walk of life. To make the admission process as simple as possible, we’ve got step-by-step guides for every kind of applicant.
The Way to Greatness Starts Here
You’re here for more than a degree. This is the time to explore your interests, build lasting relationships and take huge steps toward your future.

will take you into classrooms where innovative professors are swapping traditional lectures for practical applications and into research labs where faculty are leading their fields. And it’ll connect you to vital internships and first jobs with Fortune 500 companies (think: Coca-Cola, Delta and UPS).

Whether you dream of designing video games, reporting world news or spearheading your own startup, you’ll have the chance to pursue your passion right here. And when you leave Georgia State, you’ll have the skills to make it happen.
The ATL, the Big Peach, the A — whatever you call it, this is home.
How to Prepare for College Over Winter Break
Tour Guide Advice: Make the Most of Your Campus Visit
Whether you’re coming straight out of high school, already enrolled at another university or going back to college, we’ll walk you through the process of becoming a Panther.
Graduating high school seniors or recent high school graduates who want to start working on a bachelor’s degree at Georgia State.
Students enrolled at other colleges or universities who want to switch to Georgia State.
Foreign students living in the U.S. and American citizens living outside the U.S. who want to study at Georgia State.
Perimeter College students who want to transition to the Atlanta Campus for a bachelor’s degree program.
Start your college experience on a campus without boundaries in downtown Atlanta, where opportunities to jump-start your career are just blocks away.
If you’re a senior in high school or if you graduated from high school within the last two years, you’ll apply to begin your bachelor’s degree program using the Common Application.
Official Transcripts and Test Scores Due:
If you’re already in college but need a change, transferring to Georgia State can provide you with the opportunities you need to succeed — in school and after graduation.
If you are enrolled in an associate degree pathway at Georgia State’s Perimeter College and wish to transition to the Atlanta Campus for a bachelor’s degree program, follow our instructions for
International students need to submit the Undergraduate Application and then complete the admission process with the university’s International Student & Scholar Services.

International students include foreign students living in the U.S. on a nonimmigrant visa or going through the process of becoming permanent residents, as well as American citizens who live or have been educated outside the U.S.
If you’re enrolled in an associate degree pathway at Georgia State’s Perimeter College, we make it easy for you to move on to your bachelor’s degree.

Once you complete 30 or more credit hours with at least a 2.0 grade point average at Perimeter College, you can seamlessly transition to the Atlanta Campus for access to the largest selection of bachelor’s degree programs in the state. To be eligible, you’ll need to submit a Transition Application.
Students who graduated high school or were last enrolled in college at least five years ago.
Students who have earned a bachelor’s degree and want to take more undergraduate-level courses without pursuing another degree.
Former Georgia State students who have not registered for courses for the last three semesters.
Students enrolled at another college or university but who would like to take a few classes at Georgia State and apply their credits to their home institution.
High school juniors or seniors who want to take college courses for credit that count toward both high school and college degrees.
Does Georgia State offer an Honors College? How does a student apply? What are the benefits of participating in the Honors College?

offers high-achieving and highly motivated students the resources to excel academically and to prepare for successful professional careers. Honors students have access to individualized advisement, small classes and seminars, priority registration, special housing in the University Commons, research assistantships, and additional Study Abroad opportunities. Qualified students will automatically be reviewed for acceptance to the Honor’s College as an incoming Freshman once they have submitted all admission documents; no additional application needed. If you are a current Georgia State student, Transfer or Transition student please click
How can I check my application status and if my documents have been received?
. Once you have submitted documents, please allow 7-10 business days for the mail to be sorted and your status to be updated.
How do I apply for financial aid? When is Georgia State’s deadline for the FAFSA?
The FAFSA priority deadline is April 1. Visit
for the application process and deadlines.
I have already applied, but now can’t attend until a later semester. What can I do?

A student’s application is valid for a total of three terms of entry, including the term marked initially on the application. To be considered for a term of entry within this time frame, you must submit a

. Students who do not reactivate their application during this allotted time are required to submit a new application, new application fee and any new transcripts (if applicable) to be considered for admission.
I have already submitted my transcript to another college. Can I ask them to forward a copy to you or can you take the transferred courses off of their transcript?

Unfortunately, we are unable to do so. You must provide official transcripts from all institutions and they must arrive in a sealed envelope directly from the home institution. The transcript(s) can either be mailed directly to the Office of Undergraduate Admissions or brought in as long as it remains unopened and in the original package. Schools can mail transcripts directly to the address below.
Transcript Mailing Address (for bachelor-level students only):
As a rapidly growing public research university rooted in a major city, we’re flipping the script on the conventional college experience.
Check out our Cost Calculator, financial aid and scholarships to get an idea of what you’ll spend to attend Georgia State.
Use your Panther number to track your progress and ensure you meet deadlines and other requirements.
Use your Panther ID number to track your progress and ensure you meet deadlines and other requirements.
Our admissions counselors are here to guide you through the application and acceptance process. Connect with yours today.

See yourself joining an engaging community of expert faculty, supportive staff and motivated peers? There are many paths to get here. To make the admission process into the
as simple as possible, we’ve got step-by-step guides for every kind of student.
for Enrolled Georgia State and Transfer Students.

Whether you’re finishing up high school, already enrolled at Georgia State or transferring from another university, there’s a path for you. Click below into the category that best fits you to find out more.

Admission is limited to about the top 5-7% of the incoming first-year students each year. For best consideration for the Honors College and merit scholarships apply BEFORE November 15, 2019.

for admissions procedure and consideration: high school students who are currently enrolled in DE courses at Georgia State (either the Atlanta or one of the Perimeter campuses), OR high school students who are pursuing their DE courses at another educational institution.

. Remember to log in to College Board and send any recent test scores to Georgia State (CEEB 5251). For best consideration for the Honors College, be sure to complete and submit the reactivation form no later than November 15. An updated high school transcript (which includes in-progress senior year coursework) is required for Honors College admissions consideration.
All other Dual Enrollment students should submit the

to apply to Georgia State University; all applicants to Georgia State will be evaluated by the Honors College for Fall 2020 admission, and admissions decisions will be released beginning in mid-December.

Admission to the Honors College is for the
and is offered on a space-available basis to the most highly qualified applicants.

Application is restricted to enrolled bachelor’s degree-seeking students only. Dual enrollment/early college students at campuses other than Georgia State (Atlanta or Perimeter campuses) will be evaluated through the
Applications will open for enrolled students on March 1 and close on May 1 each year. Applicants will be notified no later than June 1 at 5 p.m.
Applicants must have completed at least 24 hours of Georgia State coursework* by the END of the spring semester.
Students with institutional GPAs (as recorded after the spring semester grade report) below 3.5 will not be considered.

Faculty/staff recommendations are required for admissions consideration. Applicants are responsible for ensuring their recommendations are received on time. Applications without recommendations will be considered incomplete.
Admission to the Honors College is highly competitive.
Incomplete or insufficient applications will not be evaluated
Applicants are responsible for ensuring all application materials, including the required faculty/staff recommendation form, are received by the Honors College by the specified deadline.
Students who wish to check their application status may email
*Fewer than 60 credit hours is strongly encouraged. Students with more than 60 credit hours will be required to supplement applications with descriptions of proposed honors coursework.
Pay attention to question prompts, including required statement length. Copying and pasting your response from a separate document is a useful strategy.
When seeking a recommendation from a faculty or staff member, you should contact your recommender to obtain permission before providing his or her name on your application.
Applicants who demonstrate interest in and knowledge of Honors College curriculum and opportunities are more likely to be selected for admission.
the May 1 submission deadline is recommended.
Students who apply at or near the May 1 deadline often have difficulty receiving the required recommendation form before the deadline.

Students who have completed at least 30 hours of coursework* while enrolled in an institution of higher education and have a minimum 3.5 transfer GPA may apply for admission to the Honors College. The application for admission to the Honors College will open for submissions on March 1 and close on May 1 each year. Applicants will be evaluated based on their transfer credit hours and cumulative grade point averages as of the completion of the spring semester. Admission to the Honors College is for the fall semester and is offered on a space-available basis to the most highly qualified applicants.

Admission to the Honors College is highly competitive. Incomplete or insufficient applications will not be evaluated by the admissions committee. Applicants are responsible for ensuring all application materials, including the required faculty/staff recommendation form, are received by the Honors College by the specified deadline. Why should I join the Honors College? What can it offer me?
The Honors College offers its students unique and exclusive opportunities for academic success and positions students to be competitive for jobs, graduate school or other post-graduate endeavors.
Personal honors advising for all four years and in all majors
Small, engaging classes taught by full-time, expert faculty
Access to honors-only, credit-bearing internships, study abroad experiences and leadership development programs
Support and guidance in applying for prestigious, competitive national scholarships and fellowships
Opportunities to work directly with faculty mentors on studies in various academic fields across campus and to showcase that work as an undergraduate
How much does it cost to be an Honors student?
There is no additional fee associated with Honors College participation. You can calculate your estimated Georgia State tuition and mandatory university fees by
Are Honors courses more difficult than general courses? I want to protect my GPA so I can maintain my scholarships.

You’ll be thrilled to know that GPAs are, on average, actually higher in our students’ Honors courses than in their non-Honors courses. It’s most likely due to the smaller class sizes we offer and the increased emphasis on student discussion and participation.
I want to see the Honors College for myself. How can I do that?
register online for a fall information session
. You can access the schedule and registration links by
. We host several sessions each fall.
If you cannot attend an information session, or you’re not an incoming, first-year student, please contact our admissions team at
We strongly encourage you to schedule a time to meet with us
Tuesdays or Fridays between 2 and 5 p.m.
I was accepted to Georgia State. Does that mean I was accepted to the Honors College?
That’s awesome! However, admittance to Georgia State does NOT guarantee acceptance into the Honors College.

Continue to actively check your email. The Honors College will notify you separately via email if you have been accepted; this message is important and will include your next steps. We only notify students who have been accepted.
High school seniors who apply by the November 15th priority consideration deadline may be notified as early as mid-December.
All other high school applicants will be notified by mid-April.
Currently enrolled Georgia State and transfer students will be notified in June.
I'm a high school senior. If I'm not accepted to the Honors College as an incoming, first-year Georgia State student, do I have any other chances?

You can apply as a currently enrolled Georgia State student toward the end of your first spring semester if you’ve successfully completed at least 24 credit hours AND you’ve maintained a Georgia State GPA of at least 3.5. More details and instructions are available under the
I'm a dual-enrolled student at Georgia State. Can I apply in the spring to the Honors College as an enrolled Georgia State student?
No. Enrolled student application is restricted to enrolled bachelors degree-seeking students only. Dual enrollment/early college students will be evaluated through the
I'm a dual-enrolled student at another institution (not Georgia State or Perimeter). How can I be evaluated for entry into the Honors College?
Dual enrollment/early college students at campuses other than Georgia State (Atlanta or Perimeter campuses) will be evaluated through the
I will be retaking the SAT/ACT after submitting my application. Will the Honors College consider my new scores?

Yes! The admissions committee continues to review newly reported scores throughout the winter and spring as we continue to form our fall class. Just make sure you report all new test scores to Georgia State through College Board and email honorsadmissions@gsu.edu to let us know you’re still interested in Honors College consideration. Even if you are not initially offered admission to the Honors College with our early admission group, we will be happy to re-evaluate your file if new scores and/or grade information is reported.
I submitted my Common Application by Nov. 15th, but my scores aren’t yet in from the testing agencies. Did I actually meet the deadline?

Yes. You met the deadline for Honors consideration, but students who have a completed application file at the time of applying will take priority over students who report scores or grades after the November 15th deadline.
I self-reported my test scores for Honors College consideration. Do I still need to have testing agencies report my scores?

Yes. Self-reported test scores are not considered official for Honors College admission requirements. You must report test scores to Georgia State (CEEB 5251) through CollegeBoard or other reporting agencies.

College of Education and Human Development’s Online Graduate Programs Ranked 35th In Nation

The Georgia State University College of Education & Human Development’s online master’s degree programs have been ranked No. 35 in the country in the U.S. News & World Report 2020 Best Online Education Programs rankings released on Jan. 14.
Georgia State University Alumni Association Announces 2020 40 Under 40 Class
Started in 2018, the Georgia State University Alumni Association's 40 Under 40 program recognizes and honors the most influential and innovative graduates who embody the values of Georgia State.
Memory of Daughter Helps Nursing Student Finish Degree
Tiffany Harris says she couldn't have completed her nursing degree without the help of friends and the words of her 12-year-old daughter Teryn, who died in July.
Georgia State Neuroscience Student Triumphs Through Transition
When Lidya Gossa came to America at the age of 7, she didn’t speak English. This week, the honors student graduates from Georgia State with a new goal — to become a surgeon.
